metadata.case_name: R. P. Kapur & Ors. v. State of Punjab & Ors.

facts.text: Petitioners are R. P. Kapur, Commissioner in State of Punjab, his wife Sheila Kapur, and mother-in-law Kaushalya Devi.

Petitioners filed writ petition under Art. 32 for enforcement of rights under Arts. 14 and 21, alleging violation by State of Punjab, Chief Minister Sardar Pratap Singh Kairon, and officials in investigation of criminal cases.

Petitioner R. P. Kapur allegedly incurred wrath of Chief Minister for not readily giving evidence in Grewal case (Karnal Murder Case) transferred to Special Judge at Delhi, trial commenced May-June 1959.
Petitioner R. P. Kapur passed orders as Commissioner Patiala Division in Sangrur case adverse to Surinder Kairon, son of Chief Minister, involving disposal of properties worth Rs. 9 lacs.

Special procedure alleged: entertainment of complaint by Chief Minister, institution by C.I.D. police, registration of FIRs after complaints, investigations in advance, by hand-picked C.I.D. officials, special C.I.D. squad.

Four cases: Sethi's case (FIR 304/1958 by M.L. Sethi), Dhingra's case (FIR 39/1959 by M.L. Dhingra), Orphanage case (FIR 135/1959 by Civil Supply Officer Karnal against State Orphanage Advisory Board and Kartar Singh), Ayurvedic Fund case (FIR 26/1960 by Daryao Singh DSP CID).
In Sethi's case, complaint dated Dec 10 1958 sent to Chief Minister, forwarded to Addl. IGP who ordered 'Register a case and investigate personally' to Hardayal Singh DSP CID Amritsar, who drew FIR.

In Dhingra's case, complaint Feb 27 1959 sent to Chief Minister alleging tampering with evidence; CM endorsed to Addl. IGP for prima facie report and seizure of papers; directed to DIG CID, then to SP CID, registered by Inspector Chandigarh, investigated by Bir Singh DSP CID.
Orphanage case: against Orphanage Advisory Board (R.P. Kapur Vice-President) and Kartar Singh for violation of Control Orders re brick kiln.

Ayurvedic Fund case: against R.P. Kapur et al. for criminal breach of trust; based on audit report re meddling with funds, payments to Kartar Singh, excess payments, purchases without quotations, use of controlled materials in private building.
Petitioners previously moved Punjab High Court to quash Sethi and Dhingra cases, unsuccessful; appeal to SC in Sethi unsuccessful; contempt petition against CM dismissed in limine.
Court finds no proof of displeasure from Grewal or Sangrur cases: Sethi/Dhingra complaints predate Grewal trial; Sangrur partition agreed before alleged adverse order.
Chief Minister filed no affidavit; affidavits by Chief Secretary, Home Secretary, officials.
CID officers superior in rank, jurisdiction over whole state per s.551 CrPC, Punjab Police Rules 21.28, 21.32, 25.14, memo 9581-H-51/7912.

legal_issues.text: Whether in the matter of institution and investigation of these cases a special procedure unknown to law has been adopted.
Whether the petitioners have been singled out for unequal treatment in administering the law relating to the institution and investigation of criminal cases in the State, attracting Art. 14.

petitioner_arguments.text: Special procedure devised circumventing CrPC: complaints entertained personally by CM, instituted by CID, FIRs after complaints, advance investigations, by hand-picked CID not empowered, special squad; violates ss.154,156,157 CrPC.
Procedure motivated by displeasure from Grewal and Sangrur cases, leading to harassment and persecution of petitioners including ladies.

respondent_arguments.text: Procedure warranted by law under s.551 CrPC; CID used due to special/technical nature of cases; no direction from CM in Sethi; no displeasure from Grewal/Sangrur.
No violation of Arts. 14,21; prior High Court rejections.

court_reasoning.text: No proof of displeasure from Grewal (cases predate) or Sangrur (partition agreed); irrelevant past record.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioners have not established incurring displeasure of Chief Minister.

court_reasoning.text: In Sethi/Dhingra: CID officers superior rank, statewide jurisdiction under s.551 CrPC; can exercise powers of station officer; not violation of ss.154,156,157; technical nature or status of accused justify CID.
Orphanage/Ayurvedic: Institution not illegal; investigation by CID valid under s.551; no specific illegality proven.
Chief Minister owed duty to file affidavit on allegations; failure causes anxiety, but no legal violation found.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Justice must not only be done but appear to be done.

holdings.text: No special procedure unknown to law adopted; no unequal treatment or violation of Arts. 14,21.

precedents_cited.case_name: H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Observations on importance of competent investigating officer; held not applicable as no mandatory violation here.
CID Inspector competent to investigate under s.157 CrPC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pulin Bihari Ghosh v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: No issue of s.551; not in point.

precedents_cited.case_name: Textile Traders Syndicate Ltd. v. State of U. P.
precedents_cited.relevance: CID Inspector superior rank, exercises s.551 powers statewide.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Alleged violation by unequal treatment and procedure affecting life/liberty; no violation found.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs FIR, investigation; s.551 empowers superior officers including CID statewide; procedure compliant.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Police Rules, 1934
statutes_cited.relevance: CID has statewide jurisdiction, assistance in technical cases.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned in Sethi complaint re concealment.

outcome.summary: Writ petition under Art.32 dismissed; no violation of Arts.14,21 found in institution/investigation procedures of four criminal cases; no order as to costs.

key_quotes.text: if a special procedure unknown to law has been adopted against the petitioners, that by itself will be a denial of the right of the equal protection of the laws.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Police officers superior in rank to an officer in charge of a police station may exercise the same powers... throughout the local area to which they are appointed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.551 CrPC, key to upholding procedure.

key_quotes.text: in an executive as well as judicial administration justice must not only be done but it must appear that justice is being done.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's observation on Chief Minister's failure to file affidavit.
